paragraphs.text: Greenfield PayCo market entry and case for change in Southeast Asia
For questions related to this document please contact any one of our team members
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
Project Qualification: ePayments Strategy for a NewCo in South East Asia
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
In support of country’s Smart Nation Payments agenda, client aims to establish a NewCo to further drive cashless adoption
Develop a national ePayment solution through NewCo that aims to:
Promote ePayments for retail and SME transactions
Establish a forward-looking view (including emerging and key trends) of the payments landscape
Determine the ways-to-play (incl. op model, target markets) for NewCo to accelerate migration to e-payments
Design infrastructure that is future ready by exploring all relevant current and potential technologies – assess suitability of existing national payments infrastructure
Explore opportunities to leverage on existing investments for the collaboration
Higher accessibility and acceptance for customers and businesses
A simplified payments system to increase competitiveness and efficiency for users
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
Increased speed of settlements via cashless payment methods
A fully regulated payments environment (e.g. establishment of the Payments Council)
In response to top-down call to action, disruptors are entering the market with two variations of digital wallet propositions
Transaction occurs directly between merchant and customer
Players acquire the consumer & merchant. Acceptance of payment is dependent on a specific application and POS terminal
Players only acquire consumers. Acceptance of payment is widely accepted with Visa and Mastercard POS terminals
Recently opened to third party developers
Source: Tech in Asia, PwC Strategy& analysis
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
While disruptors brings choice for consumers, ‘Cash’ remains the leading option for low value transactions
Players were assessed across seven lenses – payment direction, experience, interoperability, settlement speed, cost to merchants, customer reach, and fraud prevention
The payments service providers selected for assessment were filtered based on their significance in the market
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
Non-differentiating efforts by players often reap marginal benefits as user pain points remain unaddressed
Mobile payment solutions that are available (app-form) to customers upon sign up with a telco company. The mobile wallet allows for C2B and P2P transactions
Co-branded cards are collaborative efforts by a card network and a retailer to provide additional incentives to customers, usually aimed to drive shared customer loyalty
Customer experience is compromised as players try to diversify and differentiate themselves
Customers often have to take additional steps to redeem points/benefits (troublesome)
Interoperability is still lacking as payment products are limited to app users and payments are restricted to in-app and pre-approved merchants
Lack of KYC and risk management measures on customers result in defaults and bad debts – business model become unsustainable
Disruptors enter the payments landscape with intentions to maximise customer wallet-use to support core business. Discounts and incentives are offered frequently to consumers
Players are providing a buy-now pay-later service that allows customers to make a purchase and pay in instalments, assisting customers with lower cash-in-hand
Players are expected to reduce MDR in order to remain competitive and encourage merchant adoption (e.g. AMEX have reduced MDR for some merchants to 0.8% per transaction from 4.5%
Source: Company websites, Guardian, PwC Strategy& analysis
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
The country’s grassroots still prefer cash especially for low-value transactions – a habit entrenched in hearts and minds
Dominant Payment Mode: A Household’s Perspective
Cash is a norm in every household as it is simple, convenient, instant, and widely accepted
Spends on necessities and miscellaneous items – retail, transit, food
Spends only when requested by employer, mostly on household necessities
Pays via cash as it is the usual payment mode provided by the employer
Receives wages in cash and remits home to family physically
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
Provides for family, spends on household goods and meals
Pays via cash or credit/debit cards
Spends on meals, transit, and miscellaneous school items
Pays via cash as it is the form of allowance provided by parents
Spends on meals, entertainment, retail, and transit
Open to digital payments, prefers cash for small transactions
From a small merchant perspective, hawkers prefer cash due to its simplicity and the instant availability of funds
Chun Kit has to go to the market in the morning to get his supplies for the day’s work
His suppliers accepts cash as the only mode of payment
Chun Kit’s busiest hours are between 12pm to 2pm. He serves ~90 bowls of fish soup during that period at ~$4 each
A small % of customers asks about e-payments but are happy to pay cash for hawker transactions
Tan Chun Kit, 58 years old, is a hawker selling fish soup. He employs 1 stall assistant and operates between 7.30am – 4.30pm. Cash is his dominant mode of payment.
Chun Kit is the primary breadwinner of his family, which consists of his wife and 2 sons who are still in school. He currently lives in a 3-room flat.
After Chun Kit close his stall for the day, he goes to a nearby food centre to pack food for his family – cash is the only accepted payment method in the food centre
Chun Kit’s sons ask him for some money after dinner for a school excursion to the zoo – cash is the most readily available and convenient form of payment for Chun Kit
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
Example: Cash and ePayments are about cost neutral to hawkers – no compelling incentive to adopt ePayments
Case Study: Cost of Cash vs. ePayments
Chun Kit only accepts payments by cash – collecting $560 in cash per day for 140 bowls of fish soup
End of day, Chun Kit counts the total cash collected, ensuring it matches to number of bowls sold
Chun Kit goes to the bank to deposit the proceeds for the day, spending a total 1 hour for reconciliation and banking
1 hour per day of reconciliation and banking
$10 per hour opportunity cost to Chun Kit1
$20 mins per day at $10 per hour1
Chun Kit accepts ePayments for all 140 bowls of fish soup everyday, incurring 0.8% - 3.0% transaction fee
End of day, Chun Kit performs bank reconciliation to ensure proceeds received matches bowls sold
Chun Kit goes home and his work is done for the day

Note: 1) Hourly opportunity cost is based on average per hour wage adjusted for realisable savings amount of $10; 2) ~$200,000 revenue per year is based on $560 revenue per day multiplied by 365 operational days per year; 3) Transaction fee range is based on competitive rates – XXX (0.8%) to Visa / Mastercard (3.0%); 4) Profitability is assumed to be 40% of revenue at $80,000 based on average gross margins for hawkers
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
In order to encourage ePayments adoption, the cash cycle needs to be broken without affecting family needs
Soo Keng receives cash from Chun Kit and spends on daily necessities via cash– groceries, transit, and some retail spending
Cashless adoption can be facilitated by breaking the cash cycle simultaneously, lowering overall funds in circulation
Chun Kit receives funds directly into his mobile wallet without needing a physical ATM withdrawal
Funds are disbursed digitally into Soo Keng, Marc, and Maria’s e-wallets respectively
As cashless payments becomes widely adopted, Soo Keng, Marc, and Maria can perform transactions digitally without requiring physical cash
Marc receives cash from Chun Kit and spends on daily meals and miscellaneous items via cash – transit, entertainment
Chun Kit receives directly through his bank account. He proceeds to the ATM and withdraw cash to:
Provide for his mother, Soo Keng, and son, Marc
Pay monthly wages to his household helper, Maria
Maria receives cash and proceeds to the nearest 7-11 to remit cash back to her family in the Philippines
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
There are five key needs of new ePayments offering that will appeal to the People and beyond
Consumer Facing Payments Example Use Cases
Payment made via cash, card, or mobile payments – wide range of payment methods
Funds disbursed via cheque – inconvenient and lengthy payment process
Funds transfer mostly done by cash, emerging offerings with XXX
Payment made via XXX – inconvenient process with administrative requirements
Underserved – lack of instant B2C offering
Funds disbursed via XXX, increasingly using XXX – poor experience
Underserved – infra available, but poor experience
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
Underserved – lack of simple and instant C2G offering
Underserved – lack of instant G2C offering
NewCo aims to provide a unified payments infrastructure; it is not a bank, clearing house, or “another” mobile wallet
NewCo will not provide banking services to users (e.g. working capital finance, consumer loans, etc.)
NewCo will not perform functions of an automated clearing and settlement facility (e.g. require license from clearing house)
NewCo will not add to the market fragmentation of ePayments in the country but rather to unify existing payment offerings
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
Allow payers to make payments for a wide range of transactions (e.g. retail, transit, social, gaming), based on unique identifiers (e.g. xxx, xxx, mobile number)
A common standard for interoperable payments
Facilitate and authenticate payment transactions of service users
Offer solutions to support day-to-day merchant operational needs, digitising businesses
NewCo operates Wallet and Scheme, supported by the business services function and a standards arm
Enables multiple category wallets (i.e. first and third party wallets) and ‘Account-on-file’ / card-not-present transactions
Ensures interoperability between all participating entities for a wide range of activities (e.g. retail, transit, gaming, social)
Enables processing, clearing, and settlement for scheme service users
Sets and enforces scheme operating rules (e.g. dispute management, technical requirements)
Provides merchants with solutions that cater to day-to-day operational needs, including but not limited to:
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
Sets experiential standard required for service users to participate in Wallet
Leads initiatives to educate and shift public mindset to increase cashless adoption
The Wallet is a secure container that allows users to manage multiple category wallets, promoting interoperability
Wallet is a secure container / ‘Account-on-file’ that enables users to manage multiple category wallets, promoting interoperability and reducing fragmentation of digital wallets in the country
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
Category wallet providers register to participate in Wallet to enhance their respective user experience with wide access and interoperability
Consumers upload their respective sources of fund onto the Wallet account (e.g. retail, gaming, social, transit)
Consumers select the most preferred source of fund to perform a transaction (e.g. gaming wallet for gaming payments)
Consumers transact (card present and card not present) through mode offered by merchants (e.g. NFC, QR code, biometrics), enabled by ‘Account-on-file’
Service users (i.e. category wallet providers) who compete on user-base on their respective mobile applications (e.g. payment, loyalty rewards)
Consumers who want to make cashless payments and digital transactions across a wide range of channels
NewCo will allow 3rd party methods (service users) to participate in an open payments scheme
Scheme facilitates and authenticates transactions, enables processing, clearing, and settlement services, as well as sets and enforces scheme operating rules
Service user integrates and joins the scheme to leverage on the digital infrastructure provided by NewCo
Interface facilitates all transactions performed by service users within the scheme network
Enables clearing and settlement services – potentially leverage on XXX infrastructure
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
Service users (i.e. category wallet providers) who want to leverage on NewCo’s digital infrastructure to achieve interoperability, extend customer reach, and user experience
Merchants could leverage on NewCo’s digital merchant solutions to support day-to-day operational needs
Merchant services enable overlay digital solutions that cater to merchants’ day-to-day operational needs
Merchants adopt NewCo’s offering, transacting most or all payments via NewCo’s network
Merchants leverage on NewCo to enable digital merchant solutions to support business operations
NewCo enables and integrates selected digital solutions for merchants
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.

Merchants, acquired by NewCo, who want to digitise their business operations, enabling operational efficiency (e.g. e-invoicing and billing, auto reconciliation, inventory management, accounting and tax reporting, reporting and analytics)
Standard sets requirements for Wallet and Scheme to drive experience and interoperability for consumers and merchants
Standard sets technical, experiential, and operational requirements for Wallet service users, determines and enforces scheme rules, as well as boost consumer and merchant adoption
Wallet service user (i.e. category wallet providers) – subjected to wallet standard
Scheme service user – subjected to scheme rules
Wallet service user meet the set technical, experiential, and operational requirements to participate in Wallet
Scheme service user must adhere to scheme rules set by NewCo
NewCo’s offering to align to formal and informal consumer and merchant adoption levers to change public mindset and behavior towards cashless
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
The target addressable market for NewCo was identified and business case developed to substantiate the investment required
Overview of the Target Addressable Market
NewCo will be competing in the informal cash market in its initial phase – capture rate is driven by NewCo’s interoperability feature and it’s position at top-of-the-wallet
NewCo will capture debit card transactions subsequently as consumers move away from delayed to instant settlement of funds
Credit and charge card transactions will not be captured by NewCo as they offer consumers a different product proposition to NewCo, competing in a different market
As a national infrastructure, NewCo’s fees to service users will be lower than local and international ePayment players – main revenue lines include the wallet, scheme and membership fee
NewCo Wallet will be in direct competition with Google, Samsung and Apple wallet at steady state

NewCo’s costs buckets are categorised into Plan, Build, Engage, Operate and Change – largest in Build as capital is required develop the scheme infrastructure and directory required to enable interoperability
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
NewCo’s operating model and corporate structure were developed in order to maximise synergies between the Clients
A hybrid (cross) model of a Business Unit-led and Functions-led operating model is recommended for NewCo as support services are centralized and redundancies are avoided

NewCo’s target operating model is aimed to be lean and equipped with essential “run” function for NewCo’s service offering, “change” function for products and innovation , and “enable” function for product technology management and enterprise functions
NewCo is recommended to be a private company as it allows for independence, swift changes without ministerial approvals, and limited risks for NewCo

As a public infrastructure, NewCo’s Board of Directors will include a chairman, executive directors, shareholder representatives and independent board members from various backgrounds to uphold unbiased decision making
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
The high level technical architecture and implementation roadmap were developed to aid implementation of NewCo
NewCo services to include capturing payment request, transmitting messages, and verifying and authorising transactions to facilitating clearing and settlement
To capture payment requests, NewCo will leverage on existing channels (i.e. QR code) and greenfield (i.e. biometrics) in order to maximise affordability, availability, scalability and security
NewCo will provide a seamless payments experience which includes human-to-system and system-to-system interaction
As a public infrastructure, an integrated go-live model was recommended for NewCo as stakeholder socialisation and testing runs in parallel with the traditional plan, build and run
Go-live for NewCo will be fast-to-market, potentially ahead of emerging FinTech competition
Support from key stakeholders in the early stages is crucial to ensure the success of NewCo
Confidential information for the sole benefit and use of PwC’s client.
PwC refers to the PwC network and/or one or more of its member firms, each of which is a separate legal entity. Please see www.pwc.com/structure for further details.
